coredata.dc:title: Generation of a highly conductive and stable solid electrolyte interphase at lithium anode under additional electric filed
coredata.dc:creator: Chen, Yunyi
Chen, Yongxiu
Wang, Rui
Lv, Xun
Han, Yongsheng
coredata.dc:description: The solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) generated spontaneously on the surface of lithium anode, is a protective layer to inhibit further reaction of electrolyte with lithium and to prevent the formation of lithium dendrites. The composition and properties of SEI layers determine the cycling performance of lithium batteries to some extent. Here we report a novel solution to optimize the SEI layer by applying an additional alternating current (AC) electric field during the generation of SEI. The application of an AC field enhances the association of anions and cations in the electrolytes, which results in an improved delivery of anions to the surface of lithium anode. The decomposition of anions at the surface leads to the formation of an anion-derived SEI layer containing a mass of LiF and Li2S particles. The grain boundaries among these particles provide fast diffusion channels for lithium ions, forming a high conductive SEI layer. The optimized composition of SEI layer is confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis and electrochemical characterizations. Through this strategy, the cycle performance of lithium batteries is greatly improved, and the stable cycling life of Cu@Li | Li cells and Cu@Li | NMC811 cells increases more than 3 times.

AC electric field

Optimizing SEI layer by an alternating current (AC) field

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: A proposal for the optimization of SEI layer by tuning the solvation sheath via an alternating current (AC) field. (a) SEI layer with low ionic conductivity (L-SEI) generated without AC electric field, a demonstration of solvation sheath at the interface and the deposition morphologies of lithium. (b) SEI layer with high ionic conductivity (H-SEI) generated under an applied AC electric field, a demonstration of solvation sheath at the interface, and the deposition morphologies of lithium.

The evolution of solvation structure by applying an external AC field. Raman spectra of 1.0 M LiTFSI dissolved in DOL/DME (1:1) without AC electric field (a) and with AC electric field (2.5 V/cm; 80 Hz) (b). (c) RDFs (radial distribution functions) of cation–anion [Li+-O(Li+/TFSI−)] with or without AC field (Insert: Local amplification of the first peak). (d) RDFs (radial distribution functions) of cation–anion [Li+-N(Li+/TFSI−)] with or without AC field (Insert: Local amplification of the first peak). (e) The coordination number of cation–anion [Li+-O(Li+/TFSI−)] with or without AC field. (f) The coordination number of cation–anion [Li+-N(Li+/TFSI−)] with or without AC field (Insert: Partial enlargement at the first platform).

Characterizations on the SEI layers. (a) The LSV (linear sweep voltammetry) curves in the generation of SEI layer with/without AC field. (b) Current values at 1.0 V in LSV. XPS characterization of SEI components formed on Cu electrode after ten cycles of CV test within 0.1–1.3 V: (c) F 1 s, (d) S 2p.

Interfacial electrochemical characterizations. (a) Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) after the generation of SEI under different frequencies of external AC electric field (0, 20, 40, 80, 100, 120 Hz). (b) The corresponding SEI resistance (Rin) calculated from the result (a). (c) Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) after the generation of SEI under different voltages of external AC field (0, 1.0, 1.5, 2.5, 5.0 V/cm). (d) The corresponding SEI resistance (Rin) calculated from the result (c). (e) Rin at four different temperatures (275, 281, 298, 313 K). (f) The activation energy for ion diffusion in the SEI layer with or without AC field.

Lithium deposition morphologies at 1.0 mA cm−2 to 1.0 mAh cm−2 after the generation of SEI. (a)-(c) FIB-SEM images of lithium deposition with L-SEI (without AC field). (d)-(f) FIB-SEM images of lithium deposition with H-SEI (with AC field).

Cycling performance of lithium batteries with and without AC electric field in the generation of SEI layers. (a) Cycling performance and Coulombic efficiency (CE) of Li plating/stripping on Cu foil at 0.5 mA cm−2. (b) Aurbach measurement of Li metal CE in Li | Cu half cells at 0.5 mA cm−2. (c) Voltage-time curves of Cu@Li | Li coin cells. (d) The voltage profiles of the 50th and 90th cycles. (e) Cycling performance (250 mA g−1) of Cu@Li | NMC811 with and without AC electric field in the generation of SEI layers. (f) Rate capability of Cu@Li | NMC811 cells under different charging rates (0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 1.0C).

head.ce:title: Generation of a highly conductive and stable solid electrolyte interphase at lithium anode under additional electric filed

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) generated spontaneously on the surface of lithium anode, is a protective layer to inhibit further reaction of electrolyte with lithium and to prevent the formation of lithium dendrites. The composition and properties of SEI layers determine the cycling performance of lithium batteries to some extent. Here we report a novel solution to optimize the SEI layer by applying an additional alternating current (AC) electric field during the generation of SEI. The application of an AC field enhances the association of anions and cations in the electrolytes, which results in an improved delivery of anions to the surface of lithium anode. The decomposition of anions at the surface leads to the formation of an anion-derived SEI layer containing a mass of LiF and Li2S particles. The grain boundaries among these particles provide fast diffusion channels for lithium ions, forming a high conductive SEI layer. The optimized composition of SEI layer is confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis and electrochemical characterizations. Through this strategy, the cycle performance of lithium batteries is greatly improved, and the stable cycling life of Cu@Li | Li cells and Cu@Li | NMC811 cells increases more than 3 times.

ce:section.ce:para: With the increasing demand of electric vehicles and grid energy storage, high requirements were placed on the energy density and the lifespan of lithium secondary batteries (LSBs)[1–4]. To meet these requirements, lithium (Li) metal anode was returned back to the key track of future anode materials due to its high theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and low reduction potential (-3.04 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode) [5,6]. However, due to its active chemical properties, lithium metal suffers from the formation of lithium dendritic structures during the charging/discharging processs [7–9] and the side reaction with organic electrolytes [10,11]. The side reaction in the first run of charging batteries leads to the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer on the surface of lithium anode, which prevents further side reactions but increases the resistance of lithium ions transport[12,13].

In conventional lithium-sulfur electrolytes (such as 1 M LiTFSI DOL/DME), when the anions (TFSI− or FSI−) are sufficient at the anode interface, a fluorinated SEI is formed, which is composed of a large amount of lithium fluoride (LiF), and the grain boundaries among LiF are conducive to the diffusion of lithium ions[14,15]. Many strategies have been used to increase the proportion of anions at the interface to obtain fluorinated SEI[16–18]. Wang et al. used a high-concentration electrolyte (10 M LiFSI) to aggregate the FSI− in the solvation sheath, so that the anions preferentially reacted on the anode surface to form LiF-rich SEI[19]. However, the disadvantages of high-concentration electrolyte (HCE), such as high cost and high viscosity, hinder its practical application [20,21]. To overcome the above problems, Zhang et al. proposed to dilute the concentrated electrolyte by introducing an inert solvent to form a locally high concentration electrolyte (LHCE)[22]. Bis(2,2,2-trifluoroethyl) ether (BTFE) was used as an inert solvent, which is miscible with the original solvent in the electrolyte, but the lithium salt is insoluble in it. This not only ensured that the inert solvent did not change the solvation structure, but also kept the number of anions (FSI−) in the solvation sheath at a high level, forming a robust FSI-derived SEI layer, which served as a good electron barrier preventing the further reduction of electrolyte while facilitating Li+ migration, thus leading to high Coulombic efficiency (CE). But this method added new substances into the electrolyte, bringing uncertainty to battery safety, and its feasibility is limited to specific electrolytes.

In this work, we report a novel method to generate an anion-derived SEI layer at lithium anode by applying an external alternating current (AC) electric field. Since Li+ and TFSI− are charged ions, their polarities would be enhanced under the action of an electric field. TFSI ions with negative charges tend to accumulate near the Li electrode under the addition of electric field. And this phenomenon was believed to originate from strong cohesive cation–anion associations [32]. The applied electric force enhances the polarities and association of anions and cations, thereby the content of anions in the solvated structure is increased. The increase of anions (TFSI−) in the solvation sheath promotes their decomposition at the interface, resulting in an anion-derived SEI. LiF and Li2S generated by anion decomposition could effectively improve Li-ion conductivity and enhanced mechanical properties of the SEI layer[14,23]. At the same time, the direction of the AC field changes with time, so that the solvation sheath was evenly distributed on the electrode surface, which in turn promoted the homogeneity of the SEI layer. In-situ Raman spectroscopy and force field-based molecular dynamics (MD) simulation were used to detect the solvation sheath. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and electrochemical analysis were employed to disclose the effect of AC electric field on the composition and properties of SEI layers. Through focused ion beam-scanning electron microscope (FIB-SEM) characterizations, it was confirmed that the generated SEI layer could induce uniform lithium deposition. Different lithium cells were constructed to test the general role of the AC electric field on the performance of batteries.

1 M Li bis(trifluromethanesulfonyl)imide (LITFSI)-1,3-dioxolane (DOL)/1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (v/v = 1:1) were purchased from Nanjing Mojiesi Energy Technology Co., Ltd. Copper (Cu) foils were ordered from MTI Corporation. The lithium metal anodes (ø15.6 mm × 0.45 mm width) were supplied by China Energy Lithium Co., Ltd. LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 (NMC811) cathodes containing 80% wt.% of active material (Kelude Corporation), 10 wt% of conductive carbon black (MTI Corporation), and 10% wt.% of polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) (MTI Corporation) were prepared by casting the slurry in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd) onto aluminum (Al) current collector with an active material mass loading of about 3.1 mg cm−2 or 6.3 mg cm−2 followed by drying at 80 °C before use. Then, the dried cathodes were flattened by a roller press and cut into circular plate with a diameter of 18 mm to prepare for the battery electrochemical tests.

CR2032-type coin cells including Li | Cu, Cu@Li | Li, and Cu@Li | NMC811 cells were assembled in a glove box with H2O and O2 content below 1.0 ppm. Monolayer polypropylene (Celgard 2400) was used as the separator, and each cell was filled with 60 μL of electrolyte[24].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Li | Cu cells assembly and electrochemical measurements
ce:section.ce:para: For the asymmetric Li | Cu cells, the Cu foil was stamped into 18 mm disks as the working electrode, and the lithium counter electrode was 15.6 mm in diameter. Before cells assembly, the Cu electrodes were ultrasonically cleaned three times with ethanol and acetone, respectively, and vacuum-dried at 70 °C for 12 h. To form a stable SEI film, all the Li | Cu cells were cycled 10 times with constant current (50 μA) in the voltage range of 0.1–1.3 V before testing. During the generation of SEI, an external AC field was applied to regulate the solvation sheath and optimize the formation of SEI layer (Figure S1). The Li | Cu cells were charged and discharged in constant current mode on the BTS-8 multichannel battery analyzer (MTI Corporation) for comprehensive electrochemical characterization, morphology observation after lithium deposition, and Coulombic efficiency test.

The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were performed on the CHI660E electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Corporation). Among them, the frequency range of EIS test was 0.1–105 Hz, and the temperature range was 273–313 K. The test results were analyzed by Zview software, and the interface diffusion parameters were quantified by the impedance values of cells at different temperatures.

Two methods were used to test the Coulombic efficiency[24,25]. For conventional CE test consisted of the following steps: Deposited 0.5 mAh cm−2lithium on the Cu, and then stripped all lithium to 0.9 V. The above process was repeated several times. For the Aurbach CE test, a standard protocol was followed: (1) 5 mAh cm−2 of Li was first deposited on Cu foil and then stripped to 0.9 V; (2) deposited 5 mAh cm−2Li on Cu foil as a Li reservoir; (3) stripped and deposited 0.5 mAh cm−2Li, and repeated 10 times; (4) stripped lithium to 0.9 V.

The traditional CE test and Aurbach CE test were calculated by using equation (1) and equation (2), respectively:
(1)

Among them, Qs refers to the stripping capacity of each time, Qd refers to the deposition capacity of each time. Qc refers to the fixed deposition/stripping capacity (0.5 mAh cm−2), Qsf refers to the last stripping capacity and Qf refers to the pre-deposited capacity.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Cu@Li | Li cells assembly and electrochemical measurements
ce:section.ce:para: Cu@Li | Li cells were used for the examination of the electrochemical cycling performance and assembled using a Cu foil and a Li metal foil as electrodes. The Cu foil was punched into 18 mm disks as the working electrode, and the diameter of the counter Li electrode was 15.6 mm. The test steps were as follows: (1) Li | Cu cells were cycled between 0.1 and 1.3 V at 50 μA for 10 cycles to form a stable SEI on the electrodes. During this process, an AC electric field perpendicular to the direction of the internal current was applied to the outside of the cells; (2) performed one initial formation cycle with Li deposition of 10 mAh cm−2 on Cu foils and stripping to 0.9 V; (3) deposited 10 mAh cm−2 lithium on Cu foils as Li@Cu electrode; (4) Charged-discharged cycling at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Cu@Li | NMC811 cells assembly and electrochemical measurements
ce:section.ce:para: Cu@Li | NMC811 cells were used to test the rate capability and cycling performance. The diameters of Cu foils and NMC811 were 18 mm and 16.4 mm, respectively. The areal loading of cathode, anode, and separator in Cu@Li |NMC811 was 2.11 cm2, 2.11 cm2, and 2.54 cm2, respectively. The cells were assembled and tested as follows: (1) Li | Cu cells were cycled between 0.1 and 1.3 V at 50 μA for 10 cycles to form a stable SEI on the electrodes. During this process, an AC electric field perpendicular to the direction of the internal current is applied to the outside of the cells; (2) deposited 5 mAh cm−2 or 10 mAh cm−2 lithium at 0.5 mA cm−2 on Cu foils as Cu@Li electrode; (3) Assembled Cu@Li electrode and NMC811 cathode into full cells; (4) Charged-discharged tests at different rates.

The solvation structure of electrolytes was analyzed using Raman (Renishaw) spectroscopy. The chemical composition of the SEI was characterized by XPS (ESCALAB 250Xi, Thermo Fisher). The morphology of the deposited Li was determined by focused ion beam-scanning electron microscope (FIB-SEM, JIB-4700F, JEOL) and extreme high-resolution scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM 7401F, JEOL). The operation voltage of the SEM was 10.0 kV. A rough cross-sectional milling (30 kV, 1000 pA) was done on the anode by the FIB (Ga beam). Lithium deposition of 1 mAh cm−2 or 5 mAh cm−2 at a rate of 1 mA cm−2 on Cu electrode was used for morphology characterization. The morphology of lithium deposition and the integrity of SEI were explored by SEM and FIB-SEM after long-term cycles (deposited 5 mAh cm−2 lithium after the CE test at 1 mA cm−2). To remove residual salt on the electrode surface after cycling, all samples were rinsed three times with solvent and dried overnight inside the glove box, placed in an Argon-filled container to avoid the sample contacting with air during transfer process before characterization.

The forcite module in Material Studio software package (2020) was used to perform Molecular dynamics simulations to evaluate the role of the external AC field in regulating the solvation sheath. The principle of constructing a simulation system was to approach experimental conditions. Therefore, the simulation system was constructed with 715 DOL, 477 DME, and 100 LiTFSI molecules. The molecules were initially packed randomly in a cubic box with a dimension of 60 Å in length (x), width (y), and height (z) (Table S1). The simulated box size was 56.3 Å after pre-balancing in the isothermal and isobaric ensemble. A condensed-phase optimized molecular potential for atomistic simulation studies II (COMPASS II) forcefield was assigned for all the MD calculations and this field could handle systems containing both organic and inorganic molecules and simulate the exact structure and properties of condensed matter, which met the requirements of the electrolyte system in the experiment. The electrostatic interactions were accounted for using the particle–particle particle-mesh (PPPM) method. All the systems were initially stabilized for 500 steps using the smart algorithm. After geometric optimization, the simulation model was pre-equilibrated in the isothermal-isobaric ensemble (NPT, 298 K, 1 atm) for 1 ns, and then equilibrated in the canonical ensemble (NVT) for 1 ns. The time steps (NPT or NVT) for all simulations were 1 fs. Based on the trajectories of the 1 ns NVT ensemble, atomic radial distribution functions (RDFs) were used to analyze the intermolecular interaction modes. The adjustment of ac electric field frequency can be realized through “ElectricFieldPeriod”, and the oscillation period was set as: 4 ps, 1 ps, 0.01 ps. The electric field intensity was set to 1.0 V/cm, 2.5 V/cm and 5.0 V/cm respectively.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Optimizing SEI layer by an alternating current (AC) field
ce:section.ce:para: The formation of SEI layer depends on the ion’s distribution at the interface of electrode. When there are sufficient anions at the interface, the decomposition of anion during the formation of SEI layer, a highly conductive and robust SEI layer would be formed, which is called H-SEI. The anion distribution at the interface is largely dependent on the solvation sheath of Li+. As illustrated in Fig. 1 , in conventional lithium-sulfur electrolytes (1 M LiTFSI-DOL/DME (v/v = 1:1)), the solvated structure of lithium ions is generally dominated by solvent molecules (DOL and DME). Side reactions of solvent molecules at the interface tend to induce the generation of SEI with low lithium ions conductivity and poor mechanical properties (L-SEI). In this study, we hold the hypothesis that an introduction of an external AC electric field would strengthen the cohesive cation–anion association, and increase the content of anions in the solvated structure. The increase of anions (TFSI−) in the solvation sheath promotes their decomposition at the interface, resulting in anion-derived SEI. LiF and Li2S generated by anion decomposition can effectively improve Li-ion conductivity and enhance mechanical properties of the SEI layer (H-SEI)[14,23]. At the same time, the direction of the AC field changes with time, so that the solvation sheath is evenly distributed on the electrode surface, which in turn promotes the homogeneity of the SEI layer. H-SEI can weaken the concentration gradient of Li ions near the electrode surface, which in turn promotes uniform Li deposition/stripping.

To confirm the change of solvation sheath with the additional AC field, the solvation chemistries of the conventional lithium-sulfur electrolyte with or without AC field were investigated by Raman spectroscopic characterizations and force field-based molecular dynamics studies, as shown in Fig. 2 . The details of the AC field and the measurement of Raman spectroscopy are shown in Figure S1 and S2. In the lithium-sulfur electrolyte (1 M LiTFSI-DOL/DME (v/v = 1:1)), the proportion of solvated TFSI− was about 38.6%, as shown in Fig. 2a. Under the action of the external AC electric field (2.5 V/cm; 80 Hz), the proportion of solvated TFSI− increased to 41.6%, as shown in Fig. 2b, which is higher than that reported in literatures [11]. Although the increase of solvated TFSI− in Raman spectra is only 2–3%, the direct contact of the anion with the electrode surface may be greatly enhanced, allowing more TFSI- to participate in the interfacial reaction [11]. Furthermore, the effect of external electric fields on solvation sheath has been explored at different electric field strengths and frequencies. As shown in Figure S3, with the increase of electric field strength (0 V/cm-2.5 V/cm), the content of solvated TFSI− increased. This is mainly attributed to the fact that the association between anions and cations was enhanced with the increase of the electric field strength, and thus the content of TFSI− in the solvated sheath increased. But as the electric field strength continued to increase (2.5 V/cm-5.0 V/cm), the content of solvated TFSI− leveled off, which is mainly due to the exclusion of anions from electrostatic interactions. The effect of external electric field at different frequencies on the solvated TFSI− component was further explored. As depicted in Figure S4, although the anion content in the solvated structure varies little at different frequencies (41.3–41.6%), the uniformity of the solvated sheath at the interface improved with frequency. And the effect of the frequency of the applied electric field on the impedance of the SEI film would be discussed in detail in Section 3.2. The above results indicate that the external AC electric field could enhance the polarity of TFSI− and Li+, thereby improving the association between anions (TFSI−) and cations (Li+).

To further confirm the change of solvation sheath with the AC field, force field-based MD simulations were carried out to disclose the association of anions with lithium ions. The simulation system was constructed with 715 DOL, 477 DME, 100 TFSI−, and 100Li+, which gave a total of 17,097 atoms and represented 1 M LiTFSI-DOL/DME (v/v = 1:1). The simulation details are shown in Figure S5 and Table S1. The radial distribution function (RDF) was employed to describe the solvation sheath [27,28]. Fig. 2c and Fig. 2d showed the radial distribution functions of Li+-O(TFSI−) and Li+-N(TFSI−), respectively. It can be seen that whether or not an AC electric field was applied, the first peak in g(r) for Li+ appeared near 2.1 Å for both O atoms and N atoms in the anions, which is consistent with the previous reports[28]. However, the height and area of the first peak increased with the addition of AC field, indicating that the coordination number (CN) of TFSI− around the lithium ions increased (Fig. 2e and 2f). When an AC electric field (2.5 × 10−8 V/Å; 1 ps) was applied to the electrolyte, the g(r) value and the CN of Li+-F(TFSI−) also increased significantly (Figure S6), confirming that the introduction of AC electric field enhanced the association between Li+ and TFSI−. When the oscillation period and voltage of AC fields were regulated, both the height and area of the first peak near 2.1 Å changed with the adjustment, as shown in Figure S7-S9, indicating that the association between anions and cations are sensitive to the additional electric fields. The above experimental and simulation results showed that the content of TFSI− in the solvation sheath of lithium ions e increases with the introduction of AC electric fields.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Characterizations on the composition and conductivity of SEI layers
ce:section.ce:para: To investigate the effect of the AC electric field on SEI formation, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) tests were performed on Li | Cu cells at a voltage range of 0–2.0 V (0 to open circuit potential). The LSV curves of 1 M LiTFSI-DOL/DME (v/v = 1:1) showed a peak below 0.5 V, which should correspond to the underpotential deposition of lithium (Fig. 3 a). When an AC electric field (2.5 V/cm; 80 Hz) was applied to the battery, a new peak was found around 1.0 V in the LSV curve, corresponding to the decomposition of TFSI− [26,29]. Five parallel experiments were performed on LSV tests with or without an AC electric field, to calculate the current value around 1.0 V in LSV curves. As shown in Fig. 3b and Table S2, under the AC electric field, the current of TFSI− decomposition in the LSV curve reached 2.32 mA, which was nearly three times that of the control case (0.78 mA).

An increase in the decomposition of anions often leads to a subsequent change in the composition of the SEI layer. The XPS analysis was hence adopted to investigate the components of the formed SEI. The deconvolution of F 1 s spectra revealed two peaks[8], representing CFx (∼687.3 eV) and LiF (∼683.8 eV), as shown in Fig. 3c. When the AC electric field was applied, the LiF signal was greatly enhanced from 54.8% to 92.0%, indicating the improved contribution of anion decomposition during the formation of SEI layer. At the same time, the AC electric field led to the reduction of CFx content in the SEI layer from 45.2% to 8.0%, which resulted from the less contribution of organic species in the SEI formation[30]. Meanwhile, as shown in the Li 1 s spectra (Figure S10), compared to the weak LiF signal (∼56 eV) of the SEI in the control case, the addition of AC electric field during the formation of SEI resulted in an obvious peak of LiF, which was consistent well with the F 1 s spectra. The grain boundary of LiF is beneficial to the diffusion of Li ions through SEI and the uniform deposition of Li, and the grain boundary provides a fast lithium ions transport channel[31]. The decomposition of TFSI− also generated Li2S on the electrode surface, as shown in Fig. 3d, and the sulfurized SEI has abundant grain boundaries, thus providing more channels for lithium ions diffusion, resulting in higher ionic conductivity[23]. Further, we also explored the compositional changes of the SEI films after multiple cycles. As shown in Figure S11, the F 1S spectra showed that the LiF signal of H-SEI (with an external electric field applied during SEI generation) was distinct, indicating that H-SEI has good stability in the cycling. In contrast, the LiF content in the unoptimized SEI film (L-SEI) was relatively reduced. After the CE test, the H-SEI still contained part of Li2S, and the content was almost kept the same. The above results indicate that the AC electric field is beneficial to promote the decomposition of TFSI− to generate an anion-derived SEI layer with a high content of inorganic components, which would accelerate the transport of lithium ions through the SEI.

To evaluate the kinetics of lithium migration through the SEI layer formed, electrochemical characterizations were performed. 10 cycles of constant current charge–discharge process were performed at a small current of 50 μA to generate the SEI layer, and AC electric fields of different frequencies were applied during the process, followed by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis. Four times experiments were performed under each condition. The Li | Cu cells were used for the EIS tests, and the equivalent circuit model was constructed to obtain the interface resistance (Rin) (Figure S12). The as-obtained EIS profiles are shown in Fig. 4 a-4b, Figure S13, and Table S3. It was observed that when the frequency of AC electric field was less than 40 Hz, as the frequency increased, Rin tended to decrease, from 131 Ω to 107 Ω. This is most likely caused by the direction of the AC electric field changing with time, so that the solvation sheath moves with the direction of the electric field. The swing rate of the solvated sheath increases with the increase of the alternating current frequency, which also makes the solvated structure evenly distributed at the interface, thereby inducing the formation of a uniform SEI layer on the electrode surface.

However, when the AC frequency continued to increase from 40 Hz to 120 Hz, there was little change in Rin, probably because the AC electric field of 40 Hz is already sufficient to distribute the solvated sheath uniformly on the electrode surface. A direct current (DC) electric field was also tried to improve the Li-ion conductivity of the SEI layer, but the results showed that it was not as effective as an AC electric field (Figure S14), which confirmed that the AC electric field contributed to the uniform distribution of the solvated structure on the electrode surface. Moreover, the effect of AC electric field strength on the impedance of the SEI film has been deeply explored, as shown in Fig. 4c-4d, Figure S15, and Table S4. With the increase of electric field strength (0 V/cm-2.5 V/cm), the interface impedance Rin decreased. This is mainly attributed to the fact that the association between anions and cations is enhanced with the increase of the electric field strength under a smaller applied voltage, and the anions react more vigorously at the interface. However, with further increasing the electric field strength (2.5 V/cm-5.0 V/cm), Rin plateaued, mainly due to the exclusion of anions from electrostatic interactions. The results are consistent with the variation of coordination number with oscillation period and field intensity described in the previous section. Moreover, Lu et al. reported that the additional electric field of constant-voltage charging could improve the interface microenvironment, and there was also an inflection point of the increased electric field strength which achieved the optimal state of the association between anions (TFSI−) and cations (Li+) [32]. This is similar to the phenomena observed in this paper. Furthermore, a temperature-dependent electrochemical impedance spectroscopy test was performed to calculate the activation energy (Ea) of Li+ diffusion through the SEI layer. The EIS curves at different temperatures from 273 K to 313 K were shown in Fig. 4e-4f, Figure S16 and Table S5. The results showed that cells after the pretreatment of an external AC electric field exhibited a lower Ea (50.1 kJ mol−1) than the control cells (55.5 kJ mol−1), which confirmed that the anion-derived SEI (H-SEI) generated under the applied AC field has higher lithium ions conductivity. At the same time, the EIS data also reflected that the preconditioning cells with an external AC electric field did not slow down the transport of lithium ions in the electrolyte (Table S6- Table S9).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Lithium deposition at anode surface after the generation of SEI layers
ce:section.ce:para: To evaluate the effect of SEI layers on the deposition behavior of lithium, SEM and FIB-SEM were employed to evaluate the morphology of deposited lithium, as shown in Fig. 5 . SEI layer was generated at a small current of 50 μA with or without the additional AC electric field. When the SEI layer was formed without AC electric field, Li was deposited at a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2 to 1.0 mAh cm−2, and the deposition morphology of Li on the surface of Cu electrode was mainly irregular dendritic structure, as shown in Fig. 5a-5c. The reason for this may be that in the inferior SEI layer (L-SEI), the diffusion of lithium ions is limited, resulting in a lithium ions concentration gradient at the interface (high concentration outside of SEI layer and low concentration inside of SEI layer), which in turn induces the formation of lithium dendrites[33]. In contrast, after the pretreatment with an external AC electric field, the morphology of Li deposition on Cu electrodes was mainly densely-packed polyhedral particles, as shown in Fig. 5d-5e, indicating that the SEI layer formed under the AC electric field is more conducive to the uniform deposition of lithium. This may be attributed to the anion-derived SEI generated under an external AC electric field having high lithium ions conductivity, leading to a reaction-controlled lithium deposition process. Similar changes in deposition morphology were observed at a higher capacity of 5.0 mAh cm−2, as shown in Figure S17. Further, we tried to explore the morphology of lithium deposition and the integrity of SEI by SEM and FIB-SEM after long-term cycles. As shown in Figure S18a, after long-term tests, the morphology of the deposited lithium without the unoptimized SEI film (L-SEI) maintained a loose and porous structure, which is very prone to the generation of “dead lithium”. At the same time, the SEI film on the surface of lithium metal was broken, and it was difficult to observe a complete protective layer. This would lead to side reactions of the electrolyte on the anode surface and continuous consumption, which is not conducive to the stable use of the battery. In contrast, the Li deposition morphology with the optimized SEI film (H-SEI) was kept dense after long-cycle testing, although a small fraction of voids appeared in the lithium deposition. And the complete H-SEI film could be observed after multiple charge–discharge cycles, as shown in Figure S18b. The above results demonstrated that the optimized SEI could induce dense Li deposition and maintained good integrity even after multiple cycles. These results once again confirm that the applied AC electric field can optimize the formation of SEI layer with high lithium ions conductivity (H-SEI), which would benefit the stability of the lithium anode.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Cycling performance of lithium batteries with diverse SEI layers
ce:section.ce:para: To disclose the effect of the optimized SEI layer on the overall performance of batteries, cycling tests were carried out on different lithium cells. Li | Cu cells were constructed to measure Coulombic efficiency (CE). Before testing, the cells were cycled 10 times at 50 μA in the voltage range of 0.1–1.3 V to form a SEI layer on the electrodes. During the generation of SEI, an external AC field was applied to optimize the composition of the SEI layer (H-SEI). The average CE of the cell with H-SEI layer exceeded 95.3% after 150 cycles running at 0.5 mA cm−2 to 0.5 mAh cm−2, while the CE of the control cell was reduced to 40% after 80 cycles, as shown in Fig. 6 a and Figure S19. When the current density was increased to 1.0 mA cm−2, the Li | Cu cell with H-SEI still maintained a high CE after 120 cycles, while the control case declined significantly after 30 cycles, as shown in Figure S20. The Aubach method was also employed to measure the Coulombic efficiency of the cells, to make our results comparable with other reports. As shown in Fig. 6b and Figure S21, the application of an AC electric field resulted in a significant increase in CE (98.4%) compared to the control case (95.9%) running at 0.5 mA cm−2.

Compared with the CE values reported in the literatures, our result is well-competitive and listed in Table S10. When the current density was increased to 2.0 mA cm−2, the cell with H-SEI layer kept a high CE (95.4%), as shown in Figure S22, indicating the diffusion rate of lithium ions through the H-SEI layer is compatible with the high reaction rate. These results confirm that the cell pretreated with an external AC electric field has a high ionic conductivity SEI, which in turn improves the cycling performance of batteries.

Using the Cu@Li electrode instead of Li metal anode could directly and truly reflect the influence of deposition morphology induced by SEI films (H-SEI or L-SEI) on the cycle performance and service life of batteries. Therefore, Cu@Li | Li cells were constructed to explore the reversibility and polarization behavior of lithium anode, as shown in Fig. 6c. The control cell kept the voltage hysteresis overshot for nearly 100 h, while it lasted for more than 350 h when the lithium anode was covered with H-SEI. Fig. 6d showed that after the 50th cycle the overpotential of the control case (60 mV) was about 3 times that of the cell with H-SEI (20 mV). The comparison was more obvious that at the 90th cycle, the overpotential of the control case has increased sharply to 220 mV, while the overpotential of the cell with H-SEI was still maintained at about 22 mV. Furthermore, the cycling performance of the Cu@Li | NMC811 cell was studied. At a high current density (250 mA g−1), the cell optimized by the external electric field exhibited better cycling performance. As depicted in Fig. 6e and Figure S23, in the electrolytic liquid system without any additives, the Cu@Li | NMC811 full cells pretreated with an applied electric field maintained the capacity retention of more than 85% after 50 cycles. In contrast, the capacity of the control cell dropped rapidly to 0.2 mAh after 15 cycles. It indicated that SEI generated under the action of an AC electric field could induce uniform lithium deposition and improve the cycle performance of the battery. The cycle performance of the Cu@Li | NMC811 with H-SEI was compared with that of similar batteries reported in the literature. As shown in Table S11, the battery optimized by the applied electric field showed good competitiveness. In addition, Fig. 6f showed the obtained rate capability of the Cu@Li | NMC811 cells (with H-SEI or L-SEI) in the charging rate range of 0.1 to 1C, followed by a recovery at 0.1C. It was found that the difference in discharge capacities between cells with H-SEI and L-SEI layers was impressive at a high charging rate. At the charging rate of 1C, the cells with H-SEI layer retained the capacities of over 1.8 mAh while it was reduced to 1 mAh for the control cell. Figure S24 shows the corresponding galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles of the cells at the charging rate of 1C. The cell with H-SEI had the lowest voltage difference especially at high current densities, suggesting a small polarization. Hence, this phenomenon also proves the fact that the addition of an AC electric field could promote the anions-involved interfacial reaction to generate more LiF and Li2S particles in the SEI layer, and improve the conduction of lithium ions through the SEI layer, thereby enhancing the overall performance of the lithium metal batteries.

In a conclusion, we reported a novel approach to optimize the composition and properties of SEI layer by applying an additional electric field to the electrode surface of batteries during the generation of SEI. With the application of an electric field, the association of anions and cations in the electrolyte was enhanced, and a mass of anions were carried to the surface of the anode, resulting in the decomposition of anions at the surface to generate an anion-derived SEI layer with an increasing amount of LiF and Li2S. The grain boundaries among these species were beneficial to the diffusion of Li ions through SEI, forming a highly conductive anion-derived SEI layer (H-SEI). In situ Raman spectroscopy and MD simulations have been used to confirm the AC electric field induces the increase of anions in the solvation sheath of lithium ions. According to XPS analysis, the contents of LiF and Li2S in H-SEI layer formed under the AC field were greatly improved, and FIB-SEM showed that the lithium deposition under the H-SEI was dense and uniform, preventing the formation of lithium dendrites. And the stability of the H-SEI film was confirmed after long-term cycling. Diverse lithium cells were constructed to test the cycling performance of batteries with the optimized SEI layers, and the stable cycling life increased 3 and 5 times for Cu@Li | Li cells and Cu@Li | NMC811 cells, respectively. This study provides a new solution to optimize SEI layer for stable and quick cycling, and is of significance for the construction of lithium batteries, which is expected to be applied to other energy storage systems.
